Author: Ries, Al; Trout, Jack
0: The basic issue in marketing is creating a category you can be first in.
1: This is counter to classic marketing thinking, which is brand oriented: How do I get people to prefer my brand? Forget the brand. Think categories. Prospects are on the defensive when it comes to brands. Everyone talks about why their brand is better. But prospects have an open mind when it comes to categories. Everyone is interested in what’s new. Few people are interested in what’s better.
2: First and foremost, candor is very disarming. Every negative statement you make about yourself is instantly accepted as truth.
3: You have to prove a positive statement to the prospect’s satisfaction. No proof is needed for a negative statement.
4: What works in marketing is the same as what works in the military: the unexpected.
5: Equally as bad as extrapolating a trend is the common practice of assuming the future will be a replay of the present. When you assume that nothing will change, you are predicting the future just as surely as when you assume that something will change. Remember Peter’s Law: The unexpected always happens.
6: One way to cope with an unpredictable world is to build an enormous amount of flexibility into your organization. As change comes sweeping through your category, you have to be willing to change and change quickly if you are to survive in the long term.
7: Ego is the enemy of successful marketing. Objectivity is what’s needed.
8: Donald Trump and Robert Maxwell are two examples of people blinded by early success and untainted by humility. And when you’re blind, it is indeed hard to focus.
9: Actually, ego is helpful. It can be an effective driving force in building a business. What hurts is injecting your ego in the marketing process.
10: When IBM was successful, the company said very little. Now it throws a lot of press conferences. When things are going well, a company doesn’t need the hype. When you need the hype, it usually means you’re in trouble.
